Just discovered by accident that Dropbox Paper has an interestingly different style for showing keyboard shortcuts:
pasted image
Yeah, I think that display is pretty well done.
But I like ours better.

I made a new pull request #23547 to improve the keyboard shortcuts help modal.
Do you have any additional ideas or corrections?

201511059-86edf67c-506a-4e84-81d8-6dfffffa65ec.jpg
201511063-797f173d-225a-4f93-8e07-251319419a4e.jpg
201511065-1d9b7a74-a583-43b6-8071-b15cea4f2b40.jpg

Cool!

@Vlad Korobov for your thoughts.

Neat.

A small thing is that I'd go for a bit less horizontal padding inside the key pills.

I see a lot of actions that have two different shortcuts, joined by "or". For many of them, one or both of the shortcuts consists of several keys, joined by "+". In those screenshots, it's a bit confusing to read because there's no visual hierarchy -- in "A + B or C + D", nothing visually conveys that "A + B" is one group and "C + D" is another, vs. "B or C" being grouped together.

Two possible fixes for that:

  • Add more spacing around the "or". Just adding a literal space character might be enough, if it's not there already.
  • Put the alternative on a new line. See the example from Dropbox Paper above in this thread (from 2017).
One thing to note is that the pills at the top is a component we use across the app; notable at the top of settings and stream settings.

Are you referring to the things with the text "Keyboard shortcuts", "Message formatting", etc.? (I'd call those "tabs".)

By "key pills", I mean the rounded rectangles that enclose "Return", "R", etc.
The ones that are meant to evoke physical keys on a keyboard.
Yeah, I meant the tabs, aka the tab_switcher component as the codebase calls it.

Tim Abbott said:

One thing to note is that the pills at the top is a component we use across the app; notable at the top of settings and stream settings.

Yes. I'll apply this tab design to other panels as a test!

I think this switcher design works nice in other panels too.
switch_before.jpg switch_after.jpg

I added additional padding to switcher.
And in this version, I use line break instead of "or".
update_shortcut_info.jpg

Hm, I'm not sure this design is working for me in the settings panels. Spacing details aside, I think the blue draws more attention than it should; there is a lot of other info that may be more relevant to the actions the user is trying to take.

In that screenshot from the screen modal, I think the design isn't appropriate for a "tabs" style of switcher. Several problems:

  • When you have tabs, one expects that there's a panel for each tab, and when you select a different tab you see the panel that that tab is connected to. The sort order doesn't behave like this -- it's an option for how to present a single panel, not a selection of different panels -- so tabs aren't a good fit.
  • Similarly, "Subscribed" vs "All streams" isn't two different panels -- it's two filters on a single list. So tabs aren't a good fit.
  • It's weird to have two different sets of "tabs" that are simultaneously controlling a single panel. This is basically another angle on the above two points.
  • In the right half: tabs could be appropriate, as there really are three different panels. But the visual design is off. For example, those blue highlights look like they're trying to be on a dividing line between the tabs and the panel, but the design lacks such a line.

Taiki Choda said:

I added additional padding to switcher.
And in this version, I use line break instead of "or".
update_shortcut_info.jpg

The line break helps, but I think the word "or" is still needed too. Otherwise it's not clear what the relationship is between, e.g., Esc and Cmd+[.

This point still applies:

Greg Price said:

A small thing is that I'd go for a bit less horizontal padding inside the key pills.

I think it'd also be better with less vertical padding between items, so that more of them fit in view at once.

This is an interface where when someone's using it, they're typically going to have a particular thing they're looking for. If they have to scroll through lots and lots of pages to find it, that makes it harder.

Please do take a look at that example above in this thread, which I mentioned yesterday:

Tim Abbott said:

Just discovered by accident that Dropbox Paper has an interestingly different style for showing keyboard shortcuts:

image

Note how it keeps the information vertically compact. That makes it possible for the viewer to rapidly scan past a lot of items that aren't what they're looking for at that moment, to quickly get to the section that's relevant to them.

I guess until I suggested a redesigned version, I can't express fully how I would suggest to do them. My intention was to take the way keys look like in tooltips and use it.
image.png - #ADC1FF for dark theme and #7191F4 for light
I don't see the need to use +

I got it about the problems using this switcher on the setting modal.
For now, I make up the scope of this change should only be on the keyboard shortcuts modal.

keybord_shortcuts_improve_3.jpg

  • reduced gap between each rows (instead of the padding, borders are added)
  • reduced horizontal padding inside the key pills
  • + are abbreviated.
  • update key pills color

Additionally, consecutive keys are wrapped with <span> so that they are not separated by line breaks.
Hey, looks much better aligned with a future design! Thank you. Could we make corner radius for them a bit smaller? Like 5px?
And I'm not sure we should make the letters that bold. Regular might be too thin, maybe medium? Could you show how regular vs medium would look like please?
@Taiki Choda
Can you compare how many lines are shown in the new design vs. the current one? We may need to play with the vertical spacing some more.

Yeah, I think the total number of shortcuts visible on a normal size screen is important -- we want it to feel browseable without endless scrolling. Though a possible option if we want more space around the content would be to adjust the maximum height of this component to more closely match the screen; the current size of that modal is not aligned with anything else in the app.

Great, that is much improved!

Everything there looks good to me except the concern about how much is visible at a time.

With those dividers between the rows, I think the vertical padding in each row can be reduced somewhat more while still having the organization into rows (i.e., the correspondence between descriptions at the left and keychords at the right) be visually clear.
Yeah, it would be good to see a couple of versions of the padding, scrolled consistently alongside a screenshot of the current UI, so that we can easily compare how much content fits.

The old design displayed 12 rows at a time.
The modal height has been increased to display the same number of rows with a title.

ScreenShot-2022-11-17-18.41.24.jpg
ezgif-3-fcbb4bdaf3.gif

Vlad Korobov said:

And I'm not sure we should make the letters that bold. Regular might be too thin, maybe medium? Could you show how regular vs medium would look like please?

I do not know the cause, but I could not change the thickness in detail. I suggest a thinner version that is configurable.
And I set border radius 4px. (5px, there was almost no change.)
What do you think about this one?
ScreenShot-2022-11-17-19.29.38.jpg

Hm, it seems like in the proposed UI, the command description on the left line-wraps a lot more often. We've put some effort into wording things in order to minimize line-wrapping (at least in English), and I think we'd like to preserve that.

How about changing the modal width and reducing line wrapping like this?
wider.gif
How does that compare to the width of the drafts modal?

@Alya Abbott said:

How does that compare to the width of the drafts modal?

Drafts modal is wider
but its width may be too wide for keyboard shortcuts modal.

Do these two modals need to be same width?

hotkey-info-width.jpg
drafts-modal-width.jpg
wide.jpg

Do these two modals need to be same width?

No, mostly having some comparison helps me understand the proposal, which I otherwise found hard to judge from screenshots.

Anyway, I think it should be OK to bump up the modal width to reduce line wrapping. We'll need to play around with it and make sure the line wrapping looks reasonable in other languages (e.g., Russian often has longer strings), and in short and/or narrow windows. I see the current modal has some adjustments that happen as you play with the window size.

Depending on the language, there may be some additional line breaks.
However, if we make the modal wider, it may be difficult to read because the key and the description are too separated.

And modified the width so that it does not change frequently.

ezgif-3-363f130d0b.gif
Yeah, I think it's OK if there are some line breaks in other languages.

The margin on the very right looks really wide to me in the gif above. I'm wondering if it's worth doing something with the longest shortcut sequences (line break, or it looks like we actually use a smaller font currently) to avoid such a wide space there. But maybe it's OK.

Alya Abbott said:

The margin on the very right looks really wide to me in the gif above. I'm wondering if it's worth doing something with the longest shortcut sequences (line break, or it looks like we actually use a smaller font currently) to avoid such a wide space there. But maybe it's OK.

If I make the width of the right column more narrow, too separating keys and descriptions problem happen again.
So I think current one is better.

Taiki Choda said:

ezgif-3-363f130d0b.gif

@Vlad Korobov
I would like to know if there are any improvements left to complete this.
(Renamed this topic to "keyboard shortcuts reference", since it's about the reference, not the actual set of keyboard shortcuts themselves).

Taiki Choda said:

If I make the width of the right column more narrow, too separating keys and descriptions problem happen again.

Our existing design contains a solution to this problem: the keys are right-aligned, so that they're always right up next to the description.

Note that in this screenshot, the table is much wider than the particular strings here, making room in the design for longer strings in other languages or for other shortcuts — but there's no sacrifice in separating keys from descriptions:
image.png

In the one point of comparison we discussed above, Dropbox Paper, they don't use that solution.

But looking at the very next product I'd look for as a model for a keyboard-shortcuts modal, namely Gmail, they do:
image.png

Thanks Greg Price !

The reason I did not prefer right-alignment was that it made it difficult to read the text and find a shortcut.
I think the design of Gmail has solved that problem.

Can I swap columns?

Hmm, very interesting point!

Yeah, personally I think it would make a lot of sense to swap the columns for that reason. Others might have a different view, but I think it would definitely make sense to try that way and post a screenshot — that way everyone can see concretely how it works out.

I think the reason we went with the description first is that it's the thing you're looking for, but I agree it feels a bit hard to scan, and maybe the Gmail solution would be better. Certainly worth producing a screenshot of that approach with Zulip's key pills for discussion.

What you all think about this...?
